qas.question: What does the FBI feel providing general descriptions helps to facilitate?
What does the FBI employ the term race to summarize?
What does law enforcement feel appearance characteristics of individuals help them do to those individuals?
What is more important for law enforcement in categorizing instead of DNA?
What does a description of a wanted individual include beyond their racial category?

answers.text: height, weight, eye color, scars and other distinguishing characteristics.

context: In an attempt to provide general descriptions that may facilitate the <a0_0>job of law enforcement officers<a0_0/> seeking to apprehend suspects, the United States FBI employs the term "race" to summarize the <a1_0>general appearance<a1_0/> (skin color, hair texture, eye shape, and other such easily noticed characteristics) of individuals whom they are attempting to <a2_0>apprehend<a2_0/>. From the perspective of law enforcement officers, it is generally more important to <a3_0>arrive at a description<a3_0/> that will readily suggest the general appearance of an individual than to make a scientifically valid categorization by DNA or other such means. Thus, in addition to assigning a wanted individual to a racial category, such a description will include: <a4_0>height, weight, eye color, scars and other distinguishing characteristics.
